Center: OECD/NEA Nuclear Data Bank, Boulogne-Billancourt, France
ref: Jour: Annals of Nuclear Energy, Vol.15, Issue.7, p.363 (1988)
title: -Measurement of the cross section for the reaction Nb-93(n,inl)Nb-93-m at 2.8 MeV.

x4codes.shortRef: Jour: Annals of Nuclear Energy, Vol.15, Issue.7, p.363 (1988)

x4freetext: -Measurement of the cross section for the reaction
Nb-93(n,inl)Nb-93-m at 2.8 MeV.
G.Petoe.

x4codes.hlp: Inst. fuer Isotopenforschung und Kernphysik, Vienna, Austria

x4freetext: M.Wagner, G.Winkler, H.Vonach.
The neutron generator of the Institute
of Experimental Physics at Debrecen, was used to
produce a 250 micro-Amps analysed beam of 220 +/- 5 keV
deuterons.
An air-jet cooled Ti-D target thicker than the
range of the deuterons with a 0.33 mm thick Mo backing
was employed in a low-mass beam line construction.
A fission chamber with niobium and monitor
foils mounted inside and outside the chamber was
placed at 0 degrees relative to the deuterium beam.
A Si(Li) X-ray detector, 25 mm in diameter and
5 mm thick with a 0.0125 mm beryllium window, giving
a resolution of 400 eV at 17 keV, was used for the
measurement of the niobium K-shell X-radiation. The
absolute efficiency of the detector was determined by
means of a thin, point-like Nb-93m reference source.
A fission chamber, containing 168.2 +/- 2.5
micrograms of U-238, enriched to 99.98%, in
form of the compound UF4, was used. The chamber was
operated with a voltage gradient of 600 V/cm and a
continuous gas flow of pure argon counting gas. The
mass of U-238 was determined by comparing with the
activity in an aluminium foil after irradiation with
14.8 MeV neutrons, using the ratio of the well-known
cross sections for 13-Al-27(n,a)11-Na-24 and
92-U-238(n,f). The cross sections used were 112.10 mb
+/- 0.6% and 1184.4 mb +/- 1.2%, respectively.
The neutron fluence determined
with the 10 mm diameter fissionable material was
interrelated to the 20 mm diameter niobium foils by
also irradiating nickel foils with these two dia-
meters.
.Niobium foils, 20 mm diameter and with a mass of
364.24 grams, positioned 1 cm from the neutron source,
were used. The foils were irradiated for 210 hours,
resulting in a total neutron fluence of 9.0000e+12
n/cm2. Nickel foils were used for size normalisation.
A tantalum foil, 20 mm in diameter and 0.1 mm thick
was used for determining the background from tantalum
impurities in the niobium samples.
.Corrections were applied for self-absorption in the
foils and for the effects of the extension of the
source. Further, the data were corrected for fluore-
scence caused by Ta impurities in the Nb samples, for
elastic neutron scattering and for background.

x4code.headerHelp: Error in value of quantity, defined under ERR-ANALYS

x4freetext: The errors are composed of contributions
from the measurement of the Nb-93 activity and from
fluence related measurements.
.Data taken from main ref.
